mnemonic: OH LA! - Like you're impressed by something
grammar_notes: Universal greeting - works any time of day
cultural_note: The most versatile greeting - safe in any situation
tip: Start conversations with Olá + time greeting

mnemonic: BOM = Good sounds like BOMB (but good!). DIA = Day like DEER
grammar_notes: Used until around noon - literally 'good day'
cultural_note: In Portugal morning greetings are important - skip it and seem rude!
example1_en: Good morning! Did you sleep well?

mnemonic: BOA = female Good. TARDE sounds like TARDY (late in the day)
cultural_note: Switching to 'boa tarde' shows you know the time - Portuguese appreciate this precision

mnemonic: NOITE sounds like NIGHT - easy! BOA for feminine greeting
grammar_notes: Used after dark - works as both greeting AND goodbye
cultural_note: Unique: Portuguese say boa noite when arriving AND leaving at night
tip: Can say when arriving AND leaving at night
example1_pt: Boa noite! Como correu o dia?
example1_en: Good evening! How was your day?

mnemonic: A DEUS = To God - like saying 'God be with you'
grammar_notes: More formal/final goodbye - implies longer separation
cultural_note: Has a sense of finality - Portuguese use 'até' phrases for casual goodbyes instead
tip: Use for longer goodbyes - tchau for casual

mnemonic: CHOW - exactly like Italian ciao! (borrowed word)
cultural_note: Super common in casual speech - like English 'bye'. Say it twice (tchau tchau) for extra friendly!
tip: Use with friends and in casual situations

mnemonic: ATÉ = Until. LOGO = Soon. Until soon!
cultural_note: Implies you'll see the person again relatively soon - within days
tip: Most common way to say 'see you later'

mnemonic: ATÉ AMANHÃ - AMANHÃ sounds like 'a-man-YA' (imagine saying ya to a man tomorrow)
cultural_note: Use when you KNOW you'll see them the next day
tip: Specific - use when you WILL see them tomorrow

mnemonic: ATÉ JÁ - JÁ means 'already/now' - see you very soon!
grammar_notes: Very soon - within minutes or hours
cultural_note: Use when stepping away briefly - like going to bathroom or getting coffee
tip: Implies very short time - stepping out briefly
example1_en: See you soon! I'm getting coffee.

mnemonic: COMO = How (like Spanish). ESTÁ = Are (estar verb)
grammar_notes: Formal 'você' form - use with strangers or elders
cultural_note: Shows respect - always safe choice when unsure. Add 'o senhor/a senhora' for extra formality
tip: Use você form with new people or formal situations

mnemonic: ESTÁS has an S at the end = informal TU form. Think: S = friends (S-pecial people)
grammar_notes: Informal 'tu' form - the final 's' makes it informal
cultural_note: Use with friends family and people your age or younger
tip: The final 's' indicates informal tu conjugation

mnemonic: TUDO BEM = ALL GOOD. Like English 'all good?' Very versatile!
cultural_note: Common casual greeting - can be question or response. Answer the same: 'Tudo bem!'"
tip: Can answer with 'Tudo bem!' or 'Tudo ótimo!'

mnemonic: PRAZER = Pleasure - like 'pleased to meet you'
cultural_note: Used when meeting someone for the first time - often with handshake
tip: Can say just 'Prazer' or full 'Prazer em conhecer'
